page.title: 16BEEDINGS HOUSE, PULBOROUGH
page.content: At the highest point of the eastern end of the ridge, some 300 feet above sea level, stands a large four storey house called Beedings. This house of 75 rooms was built in the early 1900s by a Dr Harley who practised in London. Dr Harley was reputed to be obsessed with the danger of fire; the construction of the building was of stone and instead of timber floors, concrete was placed on rolled steel joists one yard apart. The house was also known locally as Harleys Castle or Iron Castle. Dr Harley was an enthusiast for trees and the 10 acres of grounds were planted with rhododendrons, azaleas, monkey puzzle trees and several pines. The Canadian Army occupied the house during the war. The present owner converted it into 7 flats in 1976.
